title: Acoustic Field Reconstruction in Tubes via Physics-Informed Neural Networks
author: Xinmeng Luan (McGill University), Kazuya Yokota (Nagaoka University of Technology), Gary Scavone (McGill University), ...
relevance_why: This paper explores the use of Physics-Informed Neural Networks (PINNs) for reconstructing acoustic fields, which could provide innovative methods for audio analysis and modeling, relevant for audio processing tasks that Haohe Liu focuses on.
background: Reconstructing the acoustic field in tubes based on limited and noisy pressure observation data at the radiation end, where the radiation model is unknown.
contribution: This paper introduces a framework using Physics-Informed Neural Networks (PINNs) to solve inverse problems in acoustic tube analysis, achieving reliable acoustic field reconstruction even with noise.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods relied on traditional numerical techniques like Finite Difference Method (FDM) and Finite Element Method (FEM), which may not handle noise effectively.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves upon traditional methods by incorporating physical laws within the neural network training process, enhancing robustness against noisy data.

key_innovation: Combines neural networks with physical laws to reconstruct acoustic fields in challenging conditions where radiation models are unknown.
real_world_impact: Offers a novel approach for noise-tolerant acoustic analysis in applications like musical instrument design and biomedical acoustics, potentially transforming how acoustic measurements are interpreted.
limitations: The study has only been tested under periodic boundary conditions, limiting its applicability in varied acoustic scenarios.

new_terms.Physics-Informed Neural Networks: **Physics-Informed Neural Networks (PINNs)** are a class of neural networks that integrate known physical laws into their learning process, allowing them to better predict behavior in complex systems.
new_terms.acoustic tube: **Acoustic tube** refers to a cylindrical structure through which sound waves are propagated, commonly used in the study of musical instruments and acoustics.
